captions.text: - Like people have pooped in the water,

and they cleaned it out and
all that stuff, like our poop?
Hmmm, that's cool.
Thanks for giving me poop water.

- We're here at the Orange
County Water District
Ground Water Replenishment System.

This facility takes
sewer water and treats it

to beyond drinking
water quality standards.

The water comes in from
the sewage treatment plant
and we treat it through microfiltration
to kind of remove the larger particles,
then it'll move on to...

- The second treatment
step, Reverse Osmosis.

This removes everything down
to distilled level quality,
and there's still one more treatment step.
This is basically just a redundant step
to make sure we removed anything
that's gotten through the first two steps,
which we don't think will happen.
- Tastes like water.

- I would guess this
one came from the tap.
- It's water.
That's the good stuff.
- One of these waters was once sewage.
- Oh my god!
- Oh that's cute.
- Was it B?

- I'll go with B, 'cause
it tastes a little funky.
- Hmmm, I think B was once sewage water.
- It was C.
- Oh, interesting.
- Oh my god, I can't believe that.
It tastes good!

Like, if I had to guess
I would say it was Fiji.

- 10 times out of 10 I would
rather drink sewage water
over L.A. tap water.
It's great.
That's weird.
That's really, really weird.

- I don't know what I'm
swishing around for.

I don't know, trying to get a
diaper or something in there.
That's awesome.
- I don't care.
It's poop water!

I know what's been in there,
even if it's all gone.

comments.author: Chanelle FT

comments.text:
Having been on a number of field trips to sewage treatment plants in 
school, I always just assumed tap water was sewage water (treated, of 
course). Frankly, I find it utterly ridiculous that all of it isn't, 
especially given the droughts all over much of the country (particularly 
Texas and California). Frankly, I was shocked when I just looked up that 
San Antonio, Texas is still using aquifer water, especially since they've 
been doing methane reclamation from human solid waste to power metro buses 
and the like for years now. And the yearly floods would provide a fantastic 
opportunity to grab huge quantities of water that could be stored and then 
treated over the remainder of the year to supplement other sources. Which 
is pretty much what the reservoirs their are for, but still - the floods 
are so bad they just over flow (or used to when I lived there). Hope you 
enjoyed my digression!﻿
